org.lightsleep

Class Sql<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.lightsleep.Sql<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the entity related to the main table
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable, SqlEntityInfo<E>

    public class Sql<E>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable, SqlEntityInfo<E>
    The class to build and execute SQLs.
    Java Example
     List<Contact> contacts = new ArrayList<>();
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .where("{lastName}={}", "Apple")
         .connection(conn)
         .select(contacts::add);
 });
    Groovy Example
     List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .where('{lastName}={}', 'Apple')
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it})
 }
    Generated SQL
     SELECT id, lastName, firstName, ... FROM Contact WHERE lastName='Apple'
    Since:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Masato Kokubo

      • columns

        public Sql<E> columns(java.lang.String... propertyNames)
        Specifies the property names related to the generated SELECT and UPDATE SQL columns.

        You can also be specified "*" or "<table alias>.*". If this method is not called it will be in the same as "*" is specified.

        Java Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .columns("lastName", "firstName")
         .where("{lastName}={}", "Apple")
         .connection(conn)
         .select(contacts::add);
 });
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .columns('lastName', 'firstName')
         .where('{lastName}={}', 'Apple')
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it})
 }
        Java Example
         List<Contact> contacts = new ArrayList<>();
 List<Phone> phones = new ArrayList<>();
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .innerJoin(Phone.class, "P", "{P.contactId}={C.id}")
         .columns("C.id", "P.*")
         .connection(conn)
         .<Phone>select(contacts::add, phones::add);
 });
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 List<Phone> phones = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .innerJoin(Phone, 'P', '{P.contactId}={C.id}')
         .columns('C.id', 'P.*')
         .connection(it)
         .<Phone>select({contacts << it}, {phones << it})
 }
        Parameters:
        propertyNames - an array of property names related to the columns
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if columns or any of columns is null
        See Also:
        getColumns(), setColumns(Set)

      • getColumns

      • setColumns

        public <R> Sql<E> setColumns(java.lang.Class<R> resultClass)
        Sets the set of property names included in the specified class. They are used when generating SELECT and UPDATE SQL columns.

        This method called from selectAs(Class, Consumer) and selectAs(Class).

        Type Parameters:
        R - the type of resultClass
        Parameters:
        resultClass - a class containing a set of property names to specify
        Returns:
        this object
        Since:
        2.0.0
        See Also:
        columns(String...), getColumns()

      • expression

        public Sql<E> expression(java.lang.String propertyName,
                         Expression expression)
        Associates expression with the column related to propertyName.

        If expression is empty, releases the previous association of propertyName.

        Java Example
         List<Contact> contacts = new ArrayList<>();
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .expression("firstName", "'['||{firstName}||']'")
         .where("{lastName}={}", "Orange")
         .connection(conn)
         .select(contacts::add);
 });
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .expression('firstName', "'['||{firstName}||']'")
         .where('{lastName}={}', 'Orange')
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it})
 }
        Parameters:
        propertyName - the property name
        expression - an expression
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if propertyName or expression is null
        See Also:
        getExpression(String)

      • expression

        public Sql<E> expression(java.lang.String propertyName,
                         java.lang.String content,
                         java.lang.Object... arguments)
        Associates the expression to the column related to propertyName.

        If the expression is empty, releases the previous association of propertyName.

        Parameters:

        content - a content of the expression
        arguments - arguments of the expression
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if propertyName, content or arguments is null
        See Also:
        getExpression(String), Expression.Expression(String, Object...)

      • innerJoin

        public <JE> Sql<E> innerJoin(java.lang.Class<JE> entityClass,
                             java.lang.String tableAlias,
                             Condition on)
        Add the information of the table that join with INNER JOIN.
        Java Example
         List<Contact> contacts = new ArrayList<>();
 List<Phone> phones = new ArrayList<>();
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .innerJoin(Phone.class, "P", "{P.contactId}={C.id}")
         .connection(conn)
         .<Phone>select(contacts::add, phones::add);
 });
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 List<Phone> phones = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .innerJoin(Phone, 'P', '{P.contactId}={C.id}')
         .connection(it)
         .<Phone>select({contacts << it}, {phones << it})
 }
        Type Parameters:
        JE - the type of the entity related to the table to join
        Parameters:
        entityClass - the entity class related to the table to join
        tableAlias - an alias of the table to join
        on - the join condition
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if entityClass, tableAlias or on is null
        See Also:
        getJoinInfos(), JoinInfo.JoinInfo(JoinInfo.JoinType, EntityInfo, String, Condition)

        Type Parameters:
        JE - the type of the entity related to the table to join
        Parameters:
        entityClass - the entity class related to the table to join
        tableAlias - an alias of the table to join
        on - the join condition
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if entityClass, tableAlias or on is null
        See Also:
        getJoinInfos(), JoinInfo.JoinInfo(JoinInfo.JoinType, EntityInfo, String, Condition)

      • where

        public <SE> Sql<E> where(java.lang.String content,
                         Sql<SE> subSql)
        Specifies the condition of the WHERE clause by a SubqueryCondition.
        Java Example
         List<Contact> contacts = new ArrayList<>();
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .where("EXISTS",
              new Sql<>(Phone.class, "P")
                  .where("{P.contactId}={C.id}")
                  .and("{P.content} LIKE {}", "0800001%")
         )
         .connection(conn)
         .select(contacts::add);
 });
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .where('EXISTS',
              new Sql<>(Phone, 'P')
                  .where('{P.contactId}={C.id}')
                  .and('{P.content} LIKE {}', '0800001%')
         )
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it})
 }
        Type Parameters:
        SE - the type of the entity related to the subquery
        Parameters:
        content - the left part from the SELECT statement of a subquery
        subSql - the Sql object for the subquery
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if content or subSql is null
        See Also:
        getWhere(), Condition.of(String, Sql, Sql), SubqueryCondition.SubqueryCondition(Expression, Sql, Sql)

      • doIf

        public Sql<E> doIf(boolean condition,
                   java.util.function.Consumer<Sql<E>> action)
        Executes action if condition is true.
        Java Example
         List<Contact> contacts = new ArrayList<>();
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .connection(conn)
         .doIf(!(conn.getDatabase() instanceof SQLite), Sql::forUpdate)
         .select(contacts::add);
 });
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .connection(it)
         .doIf(!(conn.database instanceof SQLite)) {it.forUpdate}
         .select({contacts << it})
 }
        Parameters:
        condition - the condition of execution
        action - an action
        Returns:
        this object
        See Also:
        doNotIf(boolean, Consumer), doElse(Consumer), doAlways(Consumer)

      • doNotIf

        public Sql<E> doNotIf(boolean condition,
                      java.util.function.Consumer<Sql<E>> action)
        Executes action if condition is false.
        Java Example
         List<Contact> contacts = new ArrayList<>();
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .connection(conn)
         .doNotIf(conn.getDatabase() instanceof SQLite, Sql::forUpdate)
         .select(contacts::add);
 });
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .connection(it)
         .doNotIf(conn.database instanceof SQLite) {it.forUpdate}
         .select({contacts << it})
 }
        Parameters:
        condition - the condition of execution
        action - an action
        Returns:
        this object
        Since:
        3.0.0
        See Also:
        doIf(boolean, Consumer), doElse(Consumer), doAlways(Consumer)

        this object

      • doIf

        @Deprecated
public Sql<E> doIf(boolean condition,
                                java.util.function.Consumer<Sql<E>> action,
                                java.util.function.Consumer<Sql<E>> elseAction)
        Deprecated. As of release 3.0.0, instead use doIf(boolean, Consumer) and doElse(Consumer)

        Executes action if condition is true, executes elseAction otherwise.

        Parameters:

        action - an action to be executed if condition is true
        elseAction - an action to be executed if condition is false

      • select

        public void select(java.util.function.Consumer<? super E> consumer)
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL that joins no tables.

        Adds following string to columns set if columns method is not called and innerJoin, leftJoin or rightJoin method called.

        • "<Main Table Alias>.*"
        Java Example
         List<Contact> contacts = new ArrayList<>();
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .connection(conn)
         .select(contacts::add);
 });
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it})
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before calling this method.

        Parameters:
        consumer - a consumer of the entities created from the ResultSet
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if consumer is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0
        See Also:
        selectAs(Class, Consumer)

      • selectAs

        public <R> void selectAs(java.lang.Class<R> resultClass,
                         java.util.function.Consumer<? super R> consumer)
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL that joins no tables.

        Adds following string to columns set if columns method is not called and innerJoin, leftJoin or rightJoin method called.

        • "<Main Table Alias>.*"
        Java Example
         List<ContactName> contactNames = new ArrayList<>();
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .connection(conn)
         .selectAs(ContactName.class, contactNames::add);
 });
        Groovy Example
         List<ContactName> contactNames = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .connection(it)
         .selectAs(ContactName, {contactNames << it})
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before calling this method.

        Type Parameters:
        R - the type of resultClass
        Parameters:
        resultClass - the class of the argumrnt of consumer
        consumer - a consumer of the entities created from the ResultSet
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if resultClass or consumer is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0
        See Also:
        select(Consumer)

      • select

        public <JE1> void select(java.util.function.Consumer<? super E> consumer,
                         java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE1> consumer1)
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL that joins one table.

        Adds following strings to columns set if columns method is not called and innerJoin, leftJoin or rightJoin method called more than once.

        • "<Main Table Alias>.*"
        • "<Joined Table Alias>.*"
        Java Example
         List<Contact> contacts = new ArrayList<>();
 List<Phone>   phones = new ArrayList<>();
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .innerJoin(Phone.class, "P", "{P.contactId}={C.id}")
         .connection(conn)
         .<Phone>select(contacts::add, phones::add);
 });
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 List<Phone>   phones = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .innerJoin(Phone, 'P', '{P.contactId}={C.id}')
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it}, {phones << it})
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before calling this method.

        Type Parameters:
        JE1 - the type of the entity related to the joined table
        Parameters:
        consumer - a consumer of the entities related to the main table created from the ResultSet
        consumer1 - a consumer of the entities related to the joined table created from the ResultSet
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if consumer or consumer1 is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if joinInfo information is less than 1
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • select

        public <JE1,JE2> void select(java.util.function.Consumer<? super E> consumer,
                             java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE1> consumer1,
                             java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE2> consumer2)
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL that joins two tables.

        Adds following strings to columns set if columns method is not called and innerJoin, leftJoin or rightJoin method called more than twice.

        • "<Main Table Alias>.*"
        • "<1st Joined Table Alias>.*"
        • "<2nd Joined Table Alias>.*"
        Java Example
         List<Contact> contacts = new ArrayList<>();
 List<Phone>   phones = new ArrayList<>();
 List<Email>   emails = new ArrayList<>();
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .innerJoin(Phone.class, "P", "{P.contactId}={C.id}")
         .innerJoin(Email.class, "E", "{E.contactId}={C.id}")
         .connection(conn)
         .<Phone, Email>select(contacts::add, phones::add, emails::add);
 });
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 List<Phone>   phones = []
 List<Email>   emails = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .innerJoin(Phone, 'P', '{P.contactId}={C.id}')
         .innerJoin(Email, 'E', '{E.contactId}={C.id}')
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it}, {phones << it}, {emails << it})
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before calling this method.

        Type Parameters:
        JE1 - the type of the entity related to the 1st joined table
        JE2 - the type of the entity related to the 2nd joined table
        Parameters:
        consumer - a consumer of the entities related to the main table created from the ResultSet
        consumer1 - a consumer of the entities related to the 1st joined table created from the ResultSet
        consumer2 - a consumer of the entities related to the 2nd joined table created from the ResultSet
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if consumer, consumer1 or consumer2 is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if join information is less than 2
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • select

        public <JE1,JE2,JE3> void select(java.util.function.Consumer<? super E> consumer,
                                 java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE1> consumer1,
                                 java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE2> consumer2,
                                 java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE3> consumer3)
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL that joins three tables.

        Adds following strings to columns set if columns method is not called and innerJoin, leftJoin or rightJoin method called more than 3 times.

        • "<Main Table Alias>.*"
        • "<1st Joined Table Alias>.*"
        • "<2nd Joined Table Alias>.*"
        • "<3rd Joined Table Alias>.*"
        Java Example
         List<Contact> contacts = new ArrayList<>();
 List<Phone>   phones = new ArrayList<>();
 List<Email>   emails = new ArrayList<>();
 List<Address> addresses = new ArrayList<>();
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .innerJoin(  Phone.class, "P", "{P.contactId}={C.id}")
         .innerJoin(  Email.class, "E", "{E.contactId}={C.id}")
         .innerJoin(Address.class, "A", "{A.contactId}={C.id}")
         .connection(conn)
         .<Phone, Email, Address>select(
             contacts::add, phones::add, emails::add, addresses::add);
 });
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 List<Phone>   phones = []
 List<Email>   emails = []
 List<Address> addresses = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .innerJoin(Phone  , 'P', '{P.contactId}={C.id}')
         .innerJoin(Email  , 'E', '{E.contactId}={C.id}')
         .innerJoin(Address, 'A', '{A.contactId}={C.id}')
         .connection(it)
         .select(
             {contacts << it}, {phones << it}, {emails << it}, {addresses << it})
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before calling this method.

        Type Parameters:
        JE1 - the type of the entity related to the 1st joined table
        JE2 - the type of the entity related to the 2nd joined table
        JE3 - the type of the entity related to the 3rd joined table
        Parameters:
        consumer - a consumer of the entities related to the main table created from the ResultSet
        consumer1 - a consumer of the entities related to the 1st joined table created from the ResultSet
        consumer2 - a consumer of the entities related to the 2nd joined table created from the ResultSet
        consumer3 - a consumer of the entities related to the 3rd joined table created from the ResultSet
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if consumer, consumer1, consumer2 or consumer3 is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if join information is less than 3
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • select

        public <JE1,JE2,JE3,JE4> void select(java.util.function.Consumer<? super E> consumer,
                                     java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE1> consumer1,
                                     java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE2> consumer2,
                                     java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE3> consumer3,
                                     java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE4> consumer4)
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL that joins four tables.

        Adds following strings to columns set if columns method is not called and innerJoin, leftJoin or rightJoin method called more than 4 times.

        • "<Main Table Alias>.*"
        • "<1st Joined Table Alias>.*"
        • "<2nd Joined Table Alias>.*"
        • "<3rd Joined Table Alias>.*"
        • "<4th Joined Table Alias>.*"
        Java Example
         List<Contact> contacts = new ArrayList<>();
 List<Phone>   phones = new ArrayList<>();
 List<Email>   emails = new ArrayList<>();
 List<Address> addresses = new ArrayList<>();
 List<Url>     urls = new ArrayList<>();
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .innerJoin(  Phone.class, "P", "{P.contactId}={C.id}")
         .innerJoin(  Email.class, "E", "{E.contactId}={C.id}")
         .innerJoin(Address.class, "A", "{A.contactId}={C.id}")
         .innerJoin(    Url.class, "U", "{U.contactId}={C.id}")
         .connection(conn)
         .<Phone, Email, Address, Url>select(
             contacts::add, phones::add, emails::add,
             addresses::add, urls::add);
 });
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 List<Phone>   phones = []
 List<Email>   emails = []
 List<Address> addresses = []
 List<Url>     urls = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .innerJoin(Phone  , 'P', '{P.contactId}={C.id}')
         .innerJoin(Email  , 'E', '{E.contactId}={C.id}')
         .innerJoin(Address, 'A', '{A.contactId}={C.id}')
         .innerJoin(Url    , 'U', '{U.contactId}={C.id}')
         .connection(it)
         .select(
             {contacts << it}, {phones << it}, {emails << it},
             {addresses << it}, {urls << it})
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before calling this method.

        Type Parameters:
        JE1 - the type of the entity related to the 1st joined table
        JE2 - the type of the entity related to the 2nd joined table
        JE3 - the type of the entity related to the 3rd joined table
        JE4 - the type of the entity related to the 4th joined table
        Parameters:
        consumer - a consumer of the entities related to the main table created from the ResultSet
        consumer1 - a consumer of the entities related to the 1st join table created from the ResultSet
        consumer2 - a consumer of the entities related to the 2nd join table created from the ResultSet
        consumer3 - a consumer of the entities related to the 3rd join table created from the ResultSet
        consumer4 - a consumer of the entities related to the 4th join table created from the ResultSet
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if consumer, consumer1, consumer2, consumer3 or consumer4 is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if join information is less than 4
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • select

        public java.util.Optional<E> select()
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL and returns an Optional of the entity if searched, Optional.empty() otherwise.
        Java Example
         Contact[] contact = new Contact[1];
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     contact[0] = new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .where("{id}={}", 1)
         .connection(conn)
         .select().orElse(null);
 });
        Groovy Example
         Contact contact
 Transaction.execute {
     contact = new Sql<>(Contact)
         .where('{id}={}', 1)
         .connection(it)
         .select().orElse(null)
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before calling this method.

        Returns:
        an Optional of the entity if searched, Optional.empty() otherwise
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        ManyRowsException - if more than one row searched
        Since:
        2.0.0
        See Also:
        selectAs(Class)

      • selectAs

        public <R> java.util.Optional<R> selectAs(java.lang.Class<R> resultClass)
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL and returns an Optional of the entity if searched, Optional.empty() otherwise.
        Java Example
         ContactName[] contactName = new ContactName[1];
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     contactName[0] = new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .where("{id}={}", 1)
         .connection(conn)
         .selectAs(ContactName.class).orElse(null);
 });
        Groovy Example
         ContactName contactName
 Transaction.execute {
     contactName = new Sql<>(Contact)
         .where('{id}={}', 1)
         .connection(it)
         .selectAs(ContactName).orElse(null)
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before calling this method.

        Type Parameters:
        R - the type of resultClass
        Parameters:
        resultClass - the class of entity to as a return value
        Returns:
        an Optional of the entity if searched, Optional.empty() otherwise
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - resultClass is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        ManyRowsException - if more than one row searched
        Since:
        2.0.0
        See Also:
        select()

      • insert

        public int insert(java.lang.Iterable<? extends E> entities)
        Generates and executes INSERT SQLs for each element of entities.
        Java Example
         int[] count = new int[1];
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     count[0] = new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .connection(conn)
         .insert(Arrays.asList(
             new Contact(7, "Harumi", "Orange", 2001, 2, 2),
             new Contact(8, "Mihaya", "Orange", 2001, 2, 3),
             new Contact(9, "Asumi" , "Orange", 2001, 2, 4)
         ));
 });
        Groovy Example
         int count
 Transaction.execute {
     count = new Sql<>(Contact)
         .connection(it)
         .insert([
             new Contact(7, 'Harumi', 'Orange', 2001, 2, 2),
             new Contact(8, 'Mihaya', 'Orange', 2001, 2, 3),
             new Contact(9, 'Asumi' , 'Orange', 2001, 2, 4)
         ])
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before calling this method.

        Parameters:
        entities - an Iterable of entities
        Returns:
        the number of rows inserted
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if entities or any element of entities is null
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • update

        public int update(E entity)
        Generates and executes an UPDATE SQL.

        If the condition of the WHERE clause is specified, updates by the condition.
        To update all rows of the target table, specify Condition.ALL to WHERE conditions.

        Java Example
         int[] count = new int[1];
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     count[0] = new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .connection(conn)
         .update(new Contact(6, "Setoka", "Orange", 2017, 2, 1));
 });
        Groovy Example
         int count
 Transaction.execute {
     count = new Sql<>(Contact)
         .connection(it)
         .update(new Contact(6, 'Setoka', 'Orange', 2017, 2, 1))
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before calling this method.

        Parameters:
        entity - the entity to be updated
        Returns:
        the number of rows updated
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if entity is null
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • update

        public int update(java.lang.Iterable<? extends E> entities)
        Generates and executes UPDATE SQLs for each element of entities.

        Even if the condition of the WHERE clause is specified, new EntityCondition(entity) will be specified for each entity.

        Java Example
         int[] count = new int[1];
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     count[0] = new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .connection(conn)
         .update(Arrays.asList(
             new Contact(7, "Harumi", "Orange", 2017, 2, 2),
             new Contact(8, "Mihaya", "Orange", 2017, 2, 3),
             new Contact(9, "Asumi" , "Orange", 2017, 2, 4)
         ));
 });
        Groovy Example
         int count
 Transaction.execute {
     count = new Sql<>(Contact)
         .connection(it)
         .update([
             new Contact(7, 'Harumi', 'Orange', 2017, 2, 2),
             new Contact(8, 'Mihaya', 'Orange', 2017, 2, 3),
             new Contact(9, 'Asumi' , 'Orange', 2017, 2, 4)
         ])
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before calling this method.

        Parameters:
        entities - an Iterable of entities
        Returns:
        the number of rows updated
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if entities or any element of entities is null
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • delete

        public int delete()
        Generates and executes a DELETE SQL.

        If the WHERE condition is not specified, dose not delete.
        To delete all rows of the target table, specify Condition.ALL to WHERE conditions.

        Java Example
         int[] count = new int[1];
 Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     count[0] = new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .where(Condition.ALL)
         .connection(conn)
         .delete();
 });
        Groovy Example
         int count
 Transaction.execute {
     count = new Sql<>(Contact)
         .where(Condition.ALL)
         .connection(it)
         .delete()
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before calling this method.

        Returns:
        the number of rows deleted
        Throws:
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0
